misconceptions.name: Implemented a different problem instead of the required number guessing game
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute the cost of a road trip instead of implementing the specified number guessing game with randomness, looping guesses, and high/low feedback.
misconceptions.student_belief: Writing a program that reads some numeric inputs and computes a cost is an acceptable solution here, even though the prompt asks for a number guessing game with random numbers and repeated guesses.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must follow the specification: generate a random secret number between 1 and 100, repeatedly prompt the user to guess until they are correct, and after each wrong guess print either "Too high" or "Too low", finally reporting how many guesses were taken.
symptoms: Program name and behavior refer to a road trip cost, not a guessing game.
No use of Random or any random number generation.
No loop structure to allow multiple guesses.
No conditional logic for "Too high" or "Too low" feedback.
Output text does not match the required guessing game interaction.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between different assignment questions or copying a solution from a different exercise without adapting it to the current specification. The student may not yet have a strong habit of mapping problem requirements to program behavior.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and list the required behaviors (random number, loop for repeated guesses, high/low feedback, correct termination condition). Then design your program structure (variables, Random object, while loop, if/else) to match that behavior before writing code.
related_concepts: Random number generation in Java (java.util.Random, nextInt)
Using loops for repeated user input
Using if/else conditionals for branching behavior
Program design and planning before coding
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High mismatch between the assigned task (guessing game) and the submitted solution (road trip cost calculator) with no elements of the required game; however, it is possible the student simply pasted the wrong file, so some uncertainty remains.

evidence.note: Entire program is a road trip cost calculator, with no random number, guessing loop, or high/low feedback as required by the number guessing game specification.

misconceptions.name: Complete task mismatch
misconceptions.description: The student submitted functional code for a problem calculating road trip cost instead of the required Number Guessing Game (Q2). This indicates a fundamental failure to address the specified assignment requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: The submitted code addresses the requirements for the current question (Q2), or this code was accidentally submitted instead of the correct solution for Q2.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The code must specifically implement a number guessing game utilizing random number generation, input loops, and conditional feedback ('Too high'/'Too low').
symptoms: Program output calculates cost instead of prompting for guesses
Missing all required game elements (loops, conditionals, random number generation)
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely an accidental submission of code intended for a different, unassigned problem, or a fundamental confusion about which task was being requested.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the requirements for Question 2 and submit the program that implements the Number Guessing Game as described. Ensure the logic includes a random number, a loop for multiple guesses, and comparison logic.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted file is unequivocally calculating road trip cost and does not contain any code related to the Number Guessing Game problem (Q2).

evidence.note: Class name reflects a problem unrelated to Q2 (Number Guessing Game).
The core logic calculates cost using three inputs, demonstrating a total lack of implementation for the game logic required by Q2.

misconceptions.name: Wrong Problem Implementation
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code for a completely different problem (road trip cost calculator) instead of the number guessing game that was assigned.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving the road trip cost problem, or may have submitted the wrong file entirely.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires implementing a number guessing game where the computer generates a random number between 1-100 and the user guesses repeatedly until correct, receiving 'Too high' or 'Too low' feedback.
symptoms: Code reads driving distance, mpg, and price per gallon instead of generating a random number
No random number generation using Random class
No conditional logic for comparing guesses to a target
Program calculates and outputs a cost instead of game feedback
misconceptions.root_cause: Student may have submitted the wrong file, misread the assignment, or copy-pasted from a previous problem without realizing the mismatch.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the assignment requirements carefully. Start fresh by implementing the number guessing game: (1) Import Random and Scanner, (2) Generate random number 1-100, (3) Create a loop that reads guesses, (4) Compare each guess and provide feedback, (5) Exit when guess equals the answer.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: 100% confidence - the submitted code implements an entirely different problem (road trip cost calculator) with no elements of the number guessing game (no Random object, no game loop, no comparison logic for guesses).

evidence.note: The entire program is for calculating road trip cost, not implementing a number guessing game. No Random object, no game loop, no 'Too high'/'Too low' logic.

misconceptions.name: Complete disregard of problem requirements
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program calculating road trip cost instead of the required number guessing game.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have copied or written a solution for a completely different programming assignment (Road Trip Cost calculation) and submitted it for this problem (Number Guessing Game).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The correct task was to implement a loop-based guessing game using random number generation and conditionals, as detailed in the prompt and rubric.
symptoms: Code calculates road trip cost instead of playing a guessing game
Required control flow structures (loops, specific conditionals) are missing
misconceptions.root_cause: Misfiling or mixing up assignments. The student likely solved another problem and submitted it here.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the specific problem description (Q2. Number Guessing Game) and implement the required logic (Generate a random number, read input repeatedly in a loop, provide 'Too high'/'Too low' feedback).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The student code computes 'RoadTripCost' using distance, MPG, and price, which has zero overlap with a number guessing game.

evidence.note: The class name and main method structure indicate a cost calculation program, not a guessing game.
The entire functional part of the code calculates a cost based on distance, MPG, and price, contrary to the guessing game requirement.
